Facility and Regulated Substances:

Solutia's nylon chemical manufacturing facilities were sold June 1, 2009, to form a new chemical company, Ascend Performance Materials, LLC.  Ascend - Decatur Plant is one of the chemical manufacturing facilities that make up the company.  Staffing at Decatur Plant is currently approximately 277 Ascend employees and approximately 86 permanent resident contractor employees.

Built in 1952, the Decatur Plant is situated on a 651.82 acre tract (peninsula), 4 miles west of the City of Decatur, on the Tennessee River (river mile 302). The peninsula is shared by guest operations.  Linde occupies 4 acres, Calpine 20 acres, Toray 50 acres, Styrolution 21 acres.  Over 300 acres are presently in use by Ascend.  The remainder acreage is the old Acrilan footprint which is currently unutilized.

The plant was designed to primarily manufacture Acrilan acrylic fiber and various nylon intermediate chemicals for the production of nylon fiber. In April of 2005, the production of Acrilan permanently ceased at this site. The bulk chemicals in the production units and tanks were subsequently removed, with completion occurring by the end of the Third Quarter of 2005. There are two toxic chemicals in our remaining processes that are regulated by EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. The RMP regulated chemicals are:

    Acrylonitrile (AN) -- A raw material to make nylon intermediate chemicals.
    Propionitrile (PN) -- A by-product from manufacture of nylon intermediate chemicals.

 4.0  General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
 
We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:
 
 * Process safety information
 * Process hazard analysis
 * Operating procedures
 * Training
 * Mechanical integrity Program
 * Management of change Process
 * Pre-startup review
 * Compliance audits
 * Incident investigation
 * Employee participation
 * Hot work permit
 * Contractors
 
As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps:
 
  Acrylonitrile (AN)
 *  Low level alarm on the tank would be triggered.  The area is also visually inspected at least twice daily.  
 *  Tank dike would minimize the release of material.  Check valves on the discharge side of the transfer pumps would prevent material from flowing back into the tank.
 *  An operator would notify the site coordinator immediately.  Cleanup would be handled by the HAZMAT team.
 *  ACAM sensors are located in the units to alarm operations when the detection of AN is present in the areas.

  Propionitrile (PN)
 * ACAM system would alarm due to high PN concentration in the air.  The sump level alarm would trigger.  This alarm can only be turned off at a location next to the tank, so someone would have to notice the release while acknowledging the alarm.  Low level alarm on the PNT Tank would go off.  The area is inspected at least twice daily.

There is an on-site emergency response team trained to handle all chemical incidents. 5.0  Five-year Accident History

On January 29, 2016 at 01:14 AM the B System separator, which is considered a covered process, experienced a deflagration.  This caused a unit shutdown that required emergency response to extinguish a fire coming from the top of the B System scrubber.  There was a minor release of AN and PN vapors, but it was not considered a reportable release.  A formal root cause analysis investigation immediately followed this event.  The investigation report is available at the Decatur site.

6.0  Emergency Response Program

We at the Decatur plant use several types of safety audits to ensure that our plant runs safely.   Following are some of the different types of audits, inspections and reviews that are conducted:  PSM and Non-PSM audits, ISO audits, Corporate and Insurance surveys and audits, Environmental and Industrial Hygiene audits, RC 14001 audits, and supervisor audits.  We conduct pre-engineering safety audits and inspections on new process before any engineering work is done.  During the phase of construction walk-through safety inspections are completed.  Pre-startup safety reviews are done before the process is started.

Ascend at Decatur, Alabama is very dedicated in preparation just in case we might have an emergency.  The entire Emergency Response Team receives CPR and First Aid/AED training.  We have approximately 35 firefighters across the 5 shifts that we work.  These firefighters train 48 hours annually at the site on incidents involving flammable liquid fires, interior fire fighting, hazardous communications, incident command and others.

 3.0  Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios

Decatur Plant used RMP*COMP (TM) software to perform the offsite consequences analyses required under the RMP rule, which implements section 112(r) of the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments.

EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios for our facility. The site maintains a list of the scenarios considered, as well as those reported, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario. This information is available at the Decatur site to appropriate inspectors.

Ascend Decatur Plant has officially adopted the following Environmental, Safety, Health and Security Policy and is committed to the success of the program: 
  
**	The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative of the Ascend Inc., Decatur Plant are committed to the implementation and maintenance of this Policy.  The commitment includes demonstrating visible leadership and involving the Site Leadership Team and other levels of the organization in the ESSH Management System.  

**	The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative are committed to openness with internal and external stakeholders.  The ESSH Management System Programs are designed to encourage dialogue regarding the RC 14001 Management System.

**	The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative are committed to the continual improvement of our environmental, safety, health, and security performance and our RC 14001 Management System, including prevention of pollution.

**	Safety is considered a core value where every person working at Ascend is entitled to a safe, healthy, and secure workplace.  In support of this value, each person working at the Decatur Plant is expected to adhere to established policies and procedures and to help identify and eliminate unsafe conditions and at-risk behaviors which can lead to accidents. 

**	The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative are committed to meet and/or exceed applicable environmental, safety, health, and security regulations, standards and other applicable environmental, safety, health and security requirements, including Responsible Care.

**	The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative continually evaluate our operation to establish and pursue objectives and targets to improve the activities, products and services which have a significant impact on the e

nvironment, safety, health and security.

**	The Plant Manager and the Responsible Care 14001 Management Representative are committed to the Responsible Care Guiding Principles and to continual Responsible Care improvement.
 
By acting on these commitments, we expect to match the best practices of our peer companies and to adhere to the Responsible Care 14001 guidelines developed by the Chemical Manufacturers Association.

1.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
 
At the Ascend - Decatur Plant, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner. We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:
 
 * A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP rule
 * A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
 * An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
 * A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
 * An overview of our emergency response program
 * An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment
 * The certifications that EPA's RMP rule requires us to provide
 * The detailed information (called data elements) about our risk management program

Our firefighters receive off-site training at fire schools such as LSU and Texas A&M.  We have two fire trucks on-site.  One fire truck is equipped with foam and another truck is equipped with dry chemical extinguishing agent to supplement the 8 fire pumps that draw fire water from the river.  

Currently, we have 9 EMTs training 24 hours annually on trauma assessment, burn care, confined space rescue and others. The EMT's receive 8 hour CPR and 1st aid training every other year.  On alternating years, the EMT's receive EVOC training.  We have a fully stocked ambulance readily available should we need to transport any of our employees to a local hospital.  Our EMTs are all nationally registered and state licensed.  

The entire fire brigade is trained to the HAZMAT technician level and are pro-board certified and will respond to on-site chemical emergencies.  We also have specialists that respond to on-site and to off-site chemical emergencies.  These dedicated people are trained to handle both railcar and highway emergencies.  They train on chemical data, shipping containers, vessels, tanks and incident command.  We have a fully stocked emergency van that carries supplies that the Specialist use to control any chemical emergencies.

Our site budgets appropriately and provides resources for projects that protect the environment, health and safety of our employees and our surrounding community.  Some examples of projects implemented are maintaining approximately 37 deluge automatic sprinkler systems, 13 smoke detection systems, 7 wet-pipe systems, 8 fire pumps, miles of underground fire mains, hundreds of fire extinguishers, and other protection equipment.
